articles.title: Threat of 'uncontrollable' bushfires as mercury soars
articles.author: Rachael Ward
articles.summary: Two states are on alert for "uncontrollable" bushfires and heatwave warnings have been issued for most of Australia. Temperatures are set to soar into the 40 degrees Celsius in some parts of the country, with the exception of Victoria.

articles.title: 80 years after the liberation of Auschwitz, the memory of the Holocaust remains contentious
articles.author: Jan Lanicek
articles.summary: The 80th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz is being commemorated in the shadow of rising antisemitism in Australia and globally. Since October 2023, Australian cities have experienced major pro-Palestinian and anti-Israel demonstrations. The opposition has proposed mandatory minimum jail terms for antisemitic acts.

articles.title: Golf club makes 11th-hour objection to plans for new 75-lot subdivision
articles.author: Helen Kempton
articles.summary: The Port Sorell Golf Club says a proposal to divide up land at Shearwater into 75 housing lots threatens its survival. It is concerned about the future of the golf club's existence. It's concerned about its future as well as the development of the land.

articles.title: Capital cities expecting hot public holiday as Melbourne braces for 41C
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Hot, dry and windy weather for Australia's south-east prompts bushfire and heatwave warnings. Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updates. Get our breaking news e-mail, free app or daily news podcast for the latest updates on the news in Australia.

articles.title: Capital cities expecting hot public holiday as Melbourne braces for 41C
articles.author: Petra Stock
articles.summary: Multiple heatwave and bushfire warnings are in place for the Australia Day public holiday. Every Australian capital city is expecting maximum temperatures above 30C. Melbourne is forecast to hit 41C, Sydney 31C, Brisbane 30C, Adelaide 35C, Perth 32C and Hobart 32C. A total fire ban has been declared for the Wimmera, Mallee, south-west, central and north central regions of Victoria.

articles.title: India's strategic southern horizon
articles.author: N Manoharan
articles.summary: Dissanayake's China visit reinforces Beijing's importance to Sri Lanka's development. India's southern neighbourhood, consisting of Sri Lanka and the Maldives, occupies a special place in its 'Neighbourhood First' policy. India has been addressing these geopolitical and security concerns at two broad levels: bilateral and multilateral.

articles.title: 'Catastrophic' coral bleaching on Great Barrier Reef turning reefs to rubble, researchers say
articles.author: Emilee Speck
articles.summary: Coral colonies in a remote area of the Great Barrier Reef suffered devastating and fatal bleaching during Australia's 2024 summer. The area has been protected from tourism and other activities for 50 years. Last year, NOAA declared the fourth-ever global coral bleaching event was underway.

articles.title: Analysis: Tropical-like conditions and hot temperatures set to impact Australia
articles.summary: Extreme fire warning for eastern parts of South Australia and western Victoria. A potential tropical cyclone could occur at the end of the week. A cool change is predicted to sweep through on Monday evening and early Tuesday morning to alleviate the high temperatures and increased fire risk.

articles.title: Warning issued to anyone with a chimney on house
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: The RSPB urges households to check their chimneys for nesting birds this spring. It's best to prevent birds nesting in chimneys as it reduces the risk of chimney fires. Some birds, such as doves and pigeons nest all year round. Jackdaws are the most common species to build nests in chimney.

articles.title: PM calls Grace Tame's T-shirt stunt ‘disrespectful'
articles.author: Lucy Slade
articles.summary: Temperatures are set to soar into the 40s in some parts of Australia. Extreme fire danger is forecast for western and central Victoria and much of eastern South Australia. A total fire ban is in place for the Wimmera, Mallee, southwest, central and north-central regions of Victoria, as well as eastern parts of South Australia including metropolitan Adelaide, Murraylands and Lower Eyre Peninsula. Heatwave warnings are current for South Australia, Queensland, NSW, ACT, Western Australia and Northern Territory.

articles.title: Lower 48 Polar Blast Coldest 'Since 1994' As Global Warming Alarmists Go Silent
articles.author: Infinite
articles.summary: Lower 48 Polar Blast is the coldest since 1994. Global Warming Alarmists are silent on the subject.      Â  .   for the next 25 years, according to Zerohedge's calculations, it will be colder than in 1994.

articles.title: Kashmir's winter turns spring-like
articles.author: Abid Bashir
articles.summary: Temperatures in Kashmir are 6 to 8 degrees above the seasonal average. Experts link the phenomenon to increasing urbanisation, unchecked pollution and climate change. Last year, Jammu and Kashmir experienced an 81 percent precipitation deficit. This year, it has recorded a shortfall of over 75 percent.

articles.title: Residents wait years in limbo as flood projections threaten dream home
articles.summary: Graham Baird has been living in a shed for more than three years as he waits to build his dream home in flood-threatened South Warrnambool. The new flood map made some blocks "effectively un-buildable", while hundreds of already-developed houses near rivers and low-lying areas were also affected. The council is negotiating a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Warrnnambool Golf Club to provide emergency access through the middle of the course in the event of a flood.

articles.title: A wake-up call
articles.summary: 2024 was the hottest year on record according to the Copernicus Report. Pakistan is already bearing the brunt of climate change. The government must take immediate action to reduce carbon emissions and invest in renewable energy and implement climate-resilient infrastructure. Climate change is not just an environmental issue, it's a humanitarian crisis.

articles.title: Marcia Langton doesn't want Peter Dutton to stand in front of the Aboriginal flag
articles.summary: Peter Dutton won't stand in front of the Aboriginal flag. Professor Marcia Langton thinks it's a political stunt in the lead up to Australia Day, centred on lies about Aboriginal people. She doesn't want Dutton anywhere near the flag. If Peter Dutton becomes the prime minister, it would mean for Aboriginal people if he becomes the PM.

articles.title: Sustainable Eating: How Your Food Choices Impact the Planet
articles.author: Watan News
articles.summary: According to researchers, a more sustainable diet can reduce the carbon footprint by up to 50%. Plant-based proteins like beans, lentils, chickpeas, and tofu require far fewer resources to produce than meat and use less water. Home gardening is an effective way to reduce carbon footprint of food.

articles.title: Watauga County to Host Agriculture Recovery Fairs presented by FEMA, State, USDA Team
articles.author: Kenneth Reece
articles.summary: Agriculture Recovery Centers are planned to help North Carolina farmers recover from Helene damage. The first locations are set for Buncombe, Henderson, McDowell and Watauga counties. Additional events are planned for Ashe, Avery, Burke, Mitchell and Yancey counties. The walk-through events will provide information on addressing agricultural or rural needs not covered by standard programs.

articles.title: Liberal Asheville's Hippies Warm to Trump
articles.author: David Marcus
articles.summary: Asheville's hardcore liberals seem to acknowledge that President Trump can be a lot more help than his predecessor in the wake of Hurricane Helene, writes David Marcus from Asheville, N.C., who is writing from the city. He says the city's liberals acknowledge that the president can be more help.

articles.title: Despite Recent Snowfalls, Most of Ocean County Remains in Extreme Drought
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: Despite recent snowfalls, most of the Southern half of the state, including Ocean County, remains in 'extreme' conditions.    "Ocean County remains in "extreme" conditions. "Ocean county is in extreme weather conditions." "Ocean counties are snow-covered.

articles.title: Scientists have shed new light on what's driven the decline of snapper in Auckland's Hauraki Gulf
articles.summary: Scientists shed light on the decline of snapper in Auckland's Hauraki Gulf. Numbers have plummeted by more than 80 percent since the arrival of humans to the area. The industrial revolution brought deforestation, agricultural expansion and urban development, which led to increased sedimentation and nutrients in estuaries. Over-fishing and new pests forced snapper to other habitats.

articles.title: Fleeting and surreal, this might be Antarctica's rarest experience
articles.author: Jenny Hewett
articles.summary: It's November 25, 2024. It's 6.49 am. Aurora Expeditions' Greg Mortimer is in the Wilhelmina Bay. The expedition company achieved B Corp status last year. It offers everything from sea kayaking to camping and skiing on certain Antarctic expeditions. Sea ice landings are rare.

articles.title: Study: Climate Change Did Not Drive Giant Kangaroos to Extinction
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: Demise of Australia's large kangaroos likely not caused by climate change, study suggests. Dental analysis suggests they were able to adapt their diet to the changing environment. The arrival of humans played a more significant role than previously thought more than 40,000 years ago. Hunters used the animals for their meat.

articles.title: Think the past will protect Australia from Trump's future? Think again
articles.author: Dr Emma Shortis
articles.summary: Trump's withdrawal from the Paris Climate Accords is one of the least surprising moves. Australia has a long history of hiding behind American recalcitrance on international climate action, but the stakes are higher now than they have ever been. Trump's ideological commitment to accelerating the cause of climate change is an active and direct security threat to Australia. A pause on US aid to the Pacific has significant geostrategic implications. Trump is building a version of violent imperial power that extends beyond this planet.

articles.title: Rising Food Costs Push Costa Rican Families Into Poverty
articles.author: Tico Times
articles.summary: Climate change has affected Costa Rica's most vulnerable people, especially in rural areas. Food basket items such as tomatoes, potatoes, eggs, and fruits have seen exponential price increases. In December alone, the prices of papaya increased by 75.21%, tomatoes by 50.68%, onions by 49.25%, and potatoes by 18.77%. Agricultural production is declining due to the spread of fungi and bacteria.

articles.title: Opinion: Trump isn't the biggest threat facing Greenland
articles.author: Lara Williams
articles.summary: Greenland is one of the few places on Earth where climate change is considered an opportunity. Warming temperatures and receding glaciers make precious minerals easier to access, extend the growing season, bring new species of fish to the self-ruling territory's waters, open up new trade routes and extend the tourism season. President Donald Trump wants to buy the territory.

articles.title: DAVID MARCUS: Liberal Asheville's hippies warm to Trump after cold shoulder from Biden
articles.author: David Marcus
articles.summary: Asheville, North Carolina is a progressive bastion in a purple state. Donald Trump visited the area devastated by Hurricane Helene and received millions of dollars in federal aid. Josh, 41, works at a brewery that has three locations, one of them survived the storm. Corey, a self-described anarchist, moved from Maine to North Carolina just weeks before the storm and his truck is totaled, but he works as a welder.

articles.title: Vanuatu AG slams Trump's Paris climate treaty exit
articles.author: postcourieronline
articles.summary: Vanuatu's top lawyer has called out the United States' 'bad behavior' after President Donald Trump withdrew the US from the Paris Agreement for a second time. Arnold Loughman led Vanuatu’s landmark International Court of Justice climate case. Fiji's Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka said Trump's action would force them to rethink their position.

articles.title: Thousands of cranes overwinter in central Nebraska: 'Past few years have been kind of crazy'
articles.author: Marjie Ducey
articles.summary: About 10,000 to 15,000 sandhill cranes have overwintered on a stretch of the Platte River from Wood River to Grand Island in central Nebraska for the winter. Last year, a polar vortex drove the birds south in January, but this year it hasn't happened. The average temperature this season has been 39.4 degrees, compared with previous season averages of 37.4. The Kearney area has received a half-inch of snow compared with normal totals of 9.6 by now.

articles.title: FORECAST: 70s and 80s on the way this week
articles.author: Andrew Shipley
articles.summary: Temperatures are running 10 degrees warmer than Saturday. Sunday will be in the mid-70s with mostly sunny skies. Most of the week will be above average in the upper 70s, around 80° by Thursday. Moderate drought is starting to settle into SWFL.

articles.title: We are in a new climate era
articles.author: Letters To The Editor
articles.summary: Scientists announced that 2024 was the hottest year on record. The world has entered a dangerous new era of chaotic floods, storms, and fires made worse by human-caused climate change. Wildfires are burning hotter and moving faster, storms are getting bigger and carrying more moisture, and soaring temperatures worldwide are leading to heat waves and drought.

articles.title: Sunday Cutdown LIX (26 January 2025)
articles.author: Thomas PM Barnett
articles.summary: Wildfires are changing the climate in the Arctic. Tundra regions may already function on average as CO 2 sources. Weight-loss drugs earn a relatively clean bill of health in a Veterans Affairs study. Oxfam report: UK's 10% took half of India's wealth during colonial era.

articles.title: Victoria activists put a new spin on Groundhog Day and climate action
articles.author: Evan Lindsay
articles.summary: Groundhog's Guide to Suing Big Oil is a free public event being held on Groundhog Day (Feb. 2) at Broadview United Church, 3703 St. Aidans St. in Victoria. The event will feature video clips and presentations from speakers who will lead discussions on local climate action. The goal is to encourage local governments to join a class-action lawsuit against big oil companies.

articles.title: Letter to the editor: We are in a new era
articles.summary: Scientists say 2024 will be the hottest year on record due to human-caused climate change. Extreme weather and searing heat killed thousands of people around the world last year and displaced millions. Al Gore has warned of the threats of Global Warming for decades. When will we stop killing our planet from burning fossil fuels to power our homes, cars and industries?

articles.title: ‘Solidarity For Green World'
articles.author: FPJ Bureau
articles.summary: UN Climate Change Conference 2024 was held in Baku, Azerbaijan, from November 11-22. Representatives from 198 countries participated, focusing on controlling global warming and developing environmental action plans. Global warming's impacts are severe and multifaceted. 87.4% of global energy resources are fossil fuel-based, with only 12.6% from renewable sources.

articles.title: David Flint on changing the date of Australia Day
articles.author: Bill Crews
articles.summary: Bill speaks with Prof. David Flint about changing the date of Australia Day. Listen to the full podcast here.      Â  .   - Bill speaks with Professor David Flint on Australia Day and changes in the date, Australia Day date.

articles.title: Australia Day Date Change
articles.author: Bill Crews
articles.summary: Bill speaks with ANU Historian, Prof. Angela Woollacott about changing the date of Australia Day. Listen to the full podcast here.   .      -   "Download this podcast here"   for a free download.

articles.title: How schools are helping to avert climate change impact
articles.summary: Learning institutions are among the leading consumers of firewood. Deforestation worsens climate change effects through increased carbon emissions. Schools are being challenged to embrace clean cooking and eco-friendly innovations to reverse the trend and help avert the climate change impact on learning institutions.

articles.title: Lower 48 Polar Blast Coldest "Since 1994" As Global Warming Alarmists Go Silent
articles.author: Edwin
articles.summary: This January will be one of the coldest since 1994. This month will finish in the top 5 coldest JANs since 1990. President Trump officially ended America's involvement in the Paris Climate Agreement last week. Al Gore will blame the cold weather on global warming.

articles.title: Public urged to take part in major UK bird count amid population fears
articles.author: Emily Beament
articles.summary: This weekend hundreds of thousands of people take part in the RSPB's annual Big Garden Birdwatch. They will spend an hour counting the birds they see in their garden, balcony, local park or other green space. The recent cold snap could have affected birds, particularly smaller species such as wrens and long-tailed tits. House sparrows have seen their count in gardens drop by a'staggering' 60% over the years.

articles.title: Opinion-Harnessing seaweed: Oman's path to carbon neutrality by 2050
articles.author: Dr. Khalid Al Subhi
articles.summary: Sultanate of Oman is trying to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. It is considering the large-scale cultivation of seaweed in coastal waters. The potential carbon sequestration from seaweed farming could reach 72 billion tons annually, potentially surpassing global carbon emissions. China would need 450,000 km² of high-yield seaweed species to meet its 2060 carbon neutrality target.

articles.title: Letter: Wildfires, floods and extreme weather -- when will we stop killing planet?
articles.author: Newark Advocate
articles.summary: Scientists say 2024 will be the hottest year on record due to human-caused climate change. Wildfires are burning hotter and moving faster, storms are getting bigger and carrying more moisture, and soaring temperatures worldwide are leading to heat waves and drought. Extreme weather and searing heat killed thousands of people last year and displaced millions.

articles.title: Kingston's fight against the rising Hudson River
articles.author: Roger Hannigan Gilson
articles.summary: Kingston will be one of the first to adapt to sea-level rise. The city is working to shore up areas along the Hudson River and Rondout Creek to mitigate future damage. It received $6 million in the state budget to rebuild part of the bulkhead along the Rond out creek in the Strand.

articles.title: Trump disparaged FEMA in North Carolina. Here's what the agency did during Hurricane Helene
articles.author: Joe Marusak
articles.summary: President Donald Trump called for the elimination of the Federal Emergency Management Agency during a visit to Hurricane Helene-ravaged Western North Carolina on Friday. FEMA deployed at least 1,500 staff members in the Southeast before the hurricane made landfall. FEMA provided more than $316 million in cash grants and $6.2 million in rental assistance to North Carolina survivors. FEMA also provided hotel stays for almost 13,000 displaced households.

articles.title: How do we learn about the environment and work to make a difference in Guelph?
articles.author: Joy Struthers Reporter
articles.summary: Grant Linney was trained by Al Gore in climate change education and empowerment. He travels to speak to groups of all ages throughout southwestern Ontario. He is looking to bring climate change into the conversation and wants to bring people's attention to the issue.

articles.title: Exploring Nature: Birds In Winter
articles.summary: Birds are cold in winter. They keep warm by fluffing up their feathers and putting on extra fat. You can help birds by supplementing their food sources and hanging up black-oil sunflower seed feeders and suet blocks. Keeps clean water in a birdbath.

articles.title: Northern and north-central Vietnam engulfed in severe cold
articles.summary: The cold front has impacted the northern and central northern provinces and parts of the central region since January 26. It will continue affecting central Vietnam and some areas in south central Vietnam for the next 24 to 48 hours. The northern and north central regions will experience severe cold, with possible frost in the northern mountains. Central Vietnam will see temperatures between 14-19°C, and Da Nang to Quang Ngai will see 16-19 °C. There will be no rain in Hanoi, with temperatures ranging from 9-12°C.

articles.title: Wild boar attacks in Barcelona down 70% in last two years
articles.author: Catalan News
articles.summary: The number of reports related to the presence of wild boars in Barcelona has dropped 70% between 2022 and 2024. The districts closer to the mountains, such as Les Corts, Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, Gràcia, Horta-Guinardó, and Nou Barris, have registered a decrease in feral pig incidents. In two years, the number of captured animals by local police has fallen from 292 to 92.

articles.title: Little birds wearing tiny backpacks can help solve big problems
articles.author: Story: 529822
articles.summary: For the past 10 years, scientists, educators and organizations have been contributing to a program that follows migratory birds on their epic journeys by outfitting them with solar-powered 'backpack' trackers no bigger than a dime. It's an ambitious international network called Motus, which is Latin for movement or motion. 34 countries contribute to the Motus database and researchers have produced more than 200 publications based on the data.

articles.title: Great Barrier Reef turnning white faster than expected, study finds
articles.summary: The Great Barrier Reef off northeastern Australia is facing worsening degradation due to climate change. The situation raises concerns for marine biodiversity and communities dependent on these vital ecosystems. The study tracked 462 coral colonies at a research station in the reef's southern region over 161 days during the global marine heatwave of 2023-2024. By February 2024, 66% of the colonies had bleached, increasing to 80% within two months. Some coral types, such as Acropora, experienced a 95% mortality rate. Goniopora corals suffered from black-band disease.

articles.title: Huge Crowds March Through Sydney Streets For 'Invasion Day' Protest
articles.author: Storyful
articles.summary: Huge crowds of protesters marched through the streets of Sydney, Australia, as part of 'Invasion Day' protests on January 26. Small clashes between Invasion Day protesters and pro-Australia Day rally attendees were disrupted by police.    via Storyful.

articles.title: Over 92,000 people affected by bad weather across Sri Lanka
articles.summary: 92,471 people from 27,751 families have been affected by the adverse weather conditions prevailing since January 13. Eastern Province has been the worst affected, with 56,878 people from 17,952 families impacted in the Ampara, Batticaloa, and Trincomalee districts. Northern Province has 29,299 people from 7,970 families. North Central Province has 4,599 people from 1,369 families. 319 houses have been partially damaged. 438 people have been moved to safe locations.

articles.title: Trumpian shockwaves
articles.author: Carmel Cacopardo
articles.summary: Donald Trump's decision to opt out of the Paris climate deal is the most consequential of the Trump decisions so far. It will trigger considerable damage on a global level which will take years to remedy. The Paris agreed target of limiting temperature rise to not more than 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial mean temperature has already been breached. There is a considerable resistance to addressing behavioural change.

articles.title: Eye on Malaysia's evolving climate reporting
articles.author: BP 3
articles.summary: The report 'Weathering the storm: Building Resilience Against Climate Disruptions' was released by the Association of Certified Accountants (ACCA). It highlights the importance of addressing the challenges posed by a distributed workforce in the face of climate crises. Only 20 per cent of the survey respondents recognise climate-related risks in their operations and only 17 per cent practice their responses to such disruptions. The report calls for immediate action to mitigate risks and adapt to inevitable changes.

articles.title: Countdown begins to farmland survey
articles.summary: Adam Henson will launch the Big Farmland Bird Count on Friday, February 7th. Farmland birds have declined by 63 per cent in the past 50 years. Adam installed supplementary feeders on his Cotswold Farm in December. He reports on the count on Countryfile.

articles.title: Australia Day has been hijacked by activists
articles.author: Terry Barnes
articles.summary: Today is Australia's national day. It marks the end of the summer and the start of the new school year. It has become an ideological plaything of Australia's professional grievance industry. Left and Aboriginal activists rebadge it as Invasion Day, protesting the arrival of Britain's First Fleet on 26 January 1788 as beginning of 200 years of colonisation and dispossession for Aboriginal Australians.

articles.title: Heat is on ... again
articles.author: Allan Murphy
articles.summary: Mildura is heading for its second-hottest day this summer on the Australia Day public holiday this Monday. The maximum temperature is 44 degrees with an extreme risk of sunburn from unprotected sun exposure. The hottest day so far this summer was 45.3 degrees on December 16.

articles.title: We Have Entered The Era Of ‘Global Boiling'—Marine Wildlife, Ecosystems, And Economies Are Being Devastated
articles.author: Un News
articles.summary: In February 2024, the average global sea surface temperature reached 21.06 degrees Celsius. The previous record of 20.98 degrees Celsius was set in August 2023. The Atlantic basin has experienced substantial heat amplification since 2016. September 2024 was the second-warmest month on record. The Mediterranean Sea reached 26.42 degrees Celsius in September 2024. Extreme heat in the oceans devastates corals and their symbiotic algae.

articles.title: Australians celebrate and protest the anniversary of British colonization
articles.author: Rod Mcguirk
articles.summary: Australia Day marks a British colony being established at Sydney Cove on Jan. 26, 1788. It led to Britain claiming the entire country without a treaty with its Indigenous inhabitants. Australians celebrated and protested across the country on Sunday as Australia Day marks the anniversary of the colony's establishment.

articles.title: Norfolk sea defences 'not affected' by partnership ending
articles.author: Owen Sennitt
articles.summary: North Norfolk District Council is the third council to leave Coastal Partnership East. East Suffolk Council and Great Yarmouth Borough Council also agreed to leave the group set up nearly a decade ago. Some fear the end of CPE could affect sea defence work taking place at Cromer and Mundesley.

articles.title: Fears sea defence work could be hampered by end of coastal partnership
articles.author: Owen Sennitt
articles.summary: North Norfolk District Council is the third council to leave Coastal Partnership East. East Suffolk Council and Great Yarmouth Borough Council also agreed to leave the group set up nearly a decade ago. Some fear the end of CPE could affect sea defence work taking place at Cromer and Mundesley.

articles.title: The Eda Davara Gala Night successfully hosted
articles.author: Michael Pais
articles.summary: The Eda Davara Gala Night aimed to raise funds for the construction of a Wet Lab at the Kohua Research Center in Barakau Village, Central Province. Dr. Eric Kwa, who attended in his capacity as the chairman of the Marine Scientific Research Committee and National Oceans Committee, delivered the keynote address.

articles.title: Lara Williams: Trump isn't the biggest threat facing Greenland
articles.summary: Greenland is one of the few places on Earth where climate change is an opportunity. The Arctic is at the frontline of the crisis, warming nearly four times faster than the global average rate between 1979 and 2021. Inuit, the indigenous peoples who make up the majority of the island's population, have seen the changes with their own eyes. The consequences are already visible, with a decline in the number of sled dogs and people moving to modern jobs from subsistence lifestyles.

articles.title: 13 First Alert Weather @ Ten: Above average temperatures return to wrap up January (1/25/25)
articles.summary: Above average temperatures return to wrap up January (1/25/25). First Alert Weather @ Ten is on at 10:00 p.m. (GMT-5:00) today.  For the rest of the day, expect above average temperatures.

articles.title: Paris Olympian signs off with another memorable Australia Day win in Wollongong
articles.summary: "It was warmer than I thought it would be, it was a bit cloudy, but then it got hotter, which I didn't mind. We want the sun shining on the harbour and everyone enjoying themselves in the sunshine on Australia Day."

articles.title: Africa Group of Negotiators list COP27 priorities for the continent
articles.author: Caroline Kimutai
articles.summary: Ephraim Mwepya Shitima of Zambia is the current Chair of the African Group of Negotiators (AGN). He met Rosalinda Soipan Tuya, the Minister of Environment and Forestry of Kenya ahead of COP27 next week. They discussed key priorities for Africa and the need to speak with one voice.

articles.title: Zimbabwe's wetlands advocates: The unsung heroes of the environment
articles.author: Gary Gerald Mtombeni
articles.summary: Wetlands are one of the most vital and diverse ecosystems on the planet. They provide a habitat for a wide range of plant and animal species. They play a critical role in regulating the climate. They help to sequester carbon dioxide, reduce the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and mitigate the impacts of climate change. They also regulate the water cycle, influencing rainfall, evaporation, and runoff. They are a depleting resource which require combined efforts to preserve and replenish for future generations. The Environmental Management Agency (Ema) is playing a crucial role in fighting to conserve wetlands in Zimbabwe. Ema issued a stop order blocking a housing development project in Greystone Park,

articles.title: Extreme heat timetables for all V/Line train services
articles.author: Riverine Herald
articles.summary: Extreme heat timetables will be in place for all lines on the V/Line network on Monday, January 27 due to forecast hot temperatures across Victoria on that day. The timetables are in place due to the forecast extreme heat temperatures across the state on Monday.

articles.title: World's largest iceberg on possible collision course with island in South Atlantic Ocean
articles.author: Andrew Wulfeck
articles.summary: A massive iceberg, A23a, is on a collision course with South Georgia Island, a British territory in the South Atlantic Ocean. The British territory is frequented by tourists and biologists interested in the pristine environment. The island has an extensive population of penguins, seals, and birds. Warming ocean temperatures contribute to the increased calving of ice.

articles.title: World's largest iceberg on possible collision course with island in South Atlantic Ocean
articles.author: Andrew Wulfeck
articles.summary: A massive iceberg, known as A23a, is on a collision course with South Georgia Island, a British territory in the South Atlantic Ocean. The British territory is not thought to have any year-round residents but is frequented by tourists and biologists interested in the pristine environment. According to NOAA, the island has an extensive population of penguins, seals, and birds in what is considered to be a more mild climate when compared to the extremes faced at the South Pole.

articles.title: Drought Warning
articles.summary: The Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) has warned about an imminent drought in Punjab. Droughts do not just threaten water availability but also endanger food security, livelihoods, and economic stability. Climate change-induced water scarcity is no longer a distant threat, it is here and its impact is intensifying. Pakistan's economy relies heavily on agriculture. The government has pushed through controversial amendments to the Prevention of Electronic Crimes Act and passed the expansive Digital Nation Pakistan Bill 2024.

articles.title: Great Lakes Ice Coverage Spiking
articles.summary: The Arctic air blasted into the Upper Midwest and Great Lakes region last week. Several days of the Arctic air sitting overhead with below-zero temperatures at night and single digits during the day allowed ice to grow. Ice coverage on Lake Michigan increased from 8% on January 17 to over 24% on Jan 25. Lake Erie is well ahead of schedule in terms of ice coverage.

articles.title: World's Largest Iceberg on Crash Course with Island; Millions of Penguins in Danger
articles.author: Abdul Moeed
articles.summary: The world's largest iceberg, A23a, is on a crash course to the British territory of South Georgia within weeks. Scientists warn the iceberg could block vital feeding routes for millions of penguins and seals, jeopardizing their survival. The island serves as a breeding ground for penguins, seals and their young.

articles.title: Is Trump about to push Ukraine to give up some of its territory to Russia?
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: There was torrential rain at the Australia Day Citizenship event in Devonport. There should have been a roofed walkway between the centre and the carpark. Bendigo Bank has a policy of not financing activities that increase the dire climate situation. The profit made by the indiscriminate release of climate poisons by big business won't help ordinary people.

articles.title: Of the options, global cooling is more likely
articles.summary: The temperature on the earth's surface is determined by radiation from the sun, which heats it, and deep space, which cools it. If the atmosphere is dirty, then climate change will take care of itself. Dave Mundell believes that if we keep the air clean, climate change won't happen.

articles.title: Analysts react to Trump's drastic move on American participation in global agreement: 'The US ... now risks forfeiting'
articles.author: Susan Elizabeth Turek
articles.summary: On Monday, President Trump signed an executive order to withdraw the United States from a global agreement to reduce harmful pollution. The agreement was signed by 196 countries and aims to limit the Earth's warming to 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit above preindustrial levels. The previous administration tapped into the burgeoning renewable energy market, adding 149,000 jobs in 2023.

articles.title: Steve Price: Melbourne sees 25,000 protesting Australia Day
articles.author: Newstalk ZB
articles.summary: Australians came out in their thousands yesterday when protesting to change the date of Australia Day. Melbourne saw around 25,000 people turn out for the protest.      .   in Melbourne yesterday. In Sydney, around 10,000 turned out.

articles.title: Cold temperatures could affect fisheries, particularly trout
articles.author: The Post
articles.summary: The S.C. Department of Natural Resources has issued a warning about the effects of the cold temperatures this week on fish in coastal South Carolina, which could have a negative impact on the environment.      Â  .   in the state.

articles.title: Lara Williams: Trump isn't the biggest threat facing Greenland
articles.author: The Citizens' Voice
articles.summary: Greenland is one of the few places on Earth where climate change is sometimes referred to as an opportunity. With the landmass no longer safely insulated by sea ice, the world is knocking on the door asking "is climate change an opportunity?".

articles.title: Sustainable Eating: How Your Food Choices Impact the Planet
articles.author: Watan
articles.summary: Watan believes that our food choices have a direct and profound impact on the planet. Our dietary system plays a pivotal role in greenhouse gas emissions, which contribute to rising temperatures and climate change.   Watan's book is called "Food and the Environment: A Global Perspective".

articles.title: Giants' rivalry in Africa: What does the continent gain from this game?
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: The world is experiencing a profound structural transformation of its global order, three decades after the end of the Cold War. At the heart of this evolution is a challenge for the future of the world's political and economic system.     .

articles.title: World's Largest Iceberg on Crash Course with Island; Millions of Penguins in Danger
articles.author: Greek Reporter
articles.summary: The world's largest iceberg is on a crash course to the British territory of South Georgia within weeks. Scientists warn the iceberg could damage the island's rich ecosystem. The iceberg is twice the size of Greater London and standing 130 feet tall and is on its way to South Georgia.

articles.title: Harnessing seaweed: Oman's path to carbon neutrality by 2050
articles.author: Oman Observer
articles.summary: As global temperatures continue to rise, the urgency for effective climate change mitigation strategies has never been more pressing. With the Sultanate of Oman striving for carbon, the need to reduce carbon emissions is even more pressing with the rise of global temperatures.

articles.title: We Have Entered The Era Of ‘Global Boiling'—Marine Wildlife, Ecosystems, And Economies Are Being Devastated
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: Marine heat waves are causing record-breaking ocean temperatures. The heat waves kill animals and impact ocean-based industries, according to the NOAA.   .   "This is a very serious problem for the ocean industry."

articles.title: Study warns against ‘oppressive heatwaves' due to global warming
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: 'Oppressive heatwaves' are caused by a combination of high temperature and high humidity. The researchers from IIT-Bombay and ETH Zurich warn that the current global warming is not the only cause of these heatwaves, but a more serious one.

articles.title: Opinion: Trump isn't the biggest threat facing Greenland
articles.author: Chatanooga Times Free Press
articles.summary: Greenland is one of the few places on Earth where climate change is sometimes referred to as an opportunity. With the landmass no longer safely insulated by sea ice, the world is knocking on the door asking "is climate change an opportunity?".

articles.title: Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane weather: How hot it will get
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: There are multiple heatwave and bushfire warnings in place in Australia on Monday. Every capital city is headed for maximum temperatures above 30C. The mercury is forecast to hit 42C in Melbourne, before a late cool change brings some relief. The heatwave is expected to last until Monday evening.

articles.title: Hurricane survivors who met Trump in North Carolina share president's words that stuck with them
articles.author: Yahoo Daily News
articles.summary: North Carolina locals survived Hurricane Helene, which hit the state on September 11th. They are sharing their stories with iReporter.com to help others who survived the hurricane.   iReport.com will let you know if you have any information about it.

articles.title: Why Australia is protesting on its national day
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: January 26 is Australia Day. It is a day of celebration for many, but also a focal point for protest and division. Indigenous people celebrate the day with barbecues, ceremonies, and festivities for Indigenous people, but for others it's about awareness of colonial history.

articles.title: We are in a new climate era
articles.author: Penn Live
articles.summary: 2024 will be the hottest year on record, according to scientists. The world has entered a new era of chaotic floods, storms and fires made worse by human-caused climate change, scientists warn.       "We're in a new age now"

articles.title: We Have Entered The Era Of ‘Global Boiling'—Marine Wildlife, Ecosystems, And Economies Are Being Devastated
articles.author: David Hastings
articles.summary: In February 2024, the average global sea surface temperature reached 21.06 degrees Celsius, the highest level ever recorded by the Copernicus Climate Change Service. The previous record of 20.98 degrees Celsius was set in August 2023. The Atlantic basin has experienced substantial heat amplification since 2016. In August 2024, Arctic Ocean's mean sea surface temperatures were between 2 and 4 degrees Celsius warmer than usual. September 2024 was the second-warmest month on record. Extreme heat in the oceans devastates coral reefs, which thrive in a narrow range of temperatures between 23 and 29 degrees Celsius.
